14.text: Server: May I help you, sir?

22.text: Server: We have pan seared registry error

23.text: sprinkled with the finest corrupted data,

29.text:
and a scripting salad with or
without polymorphic dressing,

38.text: Customer: I'd like a RAM sandwich

41.text: and a glass of your finest Code 39.

44.text: Server: Would you like any desserts, sir?

49.text:
Customer: I'd like a batch of some
zombie tracking cookies, thank you.

54.text: Your food will be served shortly.

64.text:
Maya Penn: I've been drawing ever
since I could hold a crayon,

68.text: and I've been making animated flip books

70.text: since I was three years old.

72.text:
At that age, I also learned
about what an animator was.

75.text: There was a program on TV about jobs

79.text: When I understood that an animator

81.text: makes the cartoons I saw on TV,

82.text: I immediately said, "That's what I want to be."

86.text: I don't know if I said it mentally or out loud,

89.text: but that was a greatly defining moment in my life.

92.text: Animation and art has always been my first love.

97.text: It was my love for technology that sparked the idea

101.text: There was a virus on my computer,

102.text: and I was trying to get rid of it,

104.text: and all of a sudden, I just thought,

106.text:
what if viruses have their own
little world inside the computer?

109.text: Maybe a restaurant where they meet up

116.text: At four years old, my dad showed me

118.text:
how to take apart a computer
and put it back together again.

121.text: That started my love for technology.

124.text: I built my first website myself in HTML,

127.text: and I'm learning JavaScript and Python.

129.text: I'm also working on an animated series

132.text:
It's about bees and other
pollinators in our environment

137.text: If plants aren't pollinated by the pollinators,

141.text: that depend on these plants, would starve.

144.text: So I decided to take these cool creatures

170.text: Pollinator: Deforestsaurus! I should have known!

172.text: I need to call on the rest of the Pollinators!

189.text: All of my animations start with ideas,

203.text: Ideas truly are what make the world go round.

206.text: If it wasn't for ideas, we wouldn't be

209.text: where we are now with technology, medicine,

211.text: art, culture, and how we even live our lives.

215.text: At eight years old, I took my ideas

217.text: and started my own business called Maya's Ideas,

220.text: and my nonprofit, Maya's Ideas for the Planet.

224.text: And I make eco-friendly clothing and accessories.

228.text: I'm 13 now, and although I started my business

232.text: my artistic journey started way before then.

235.text: I was greatly influenced by art, and I wanted to

237.text: incorporate it in everything I did, even my business.

241.text: I would find different fabrics around the house,

243.text: and say, "This could be a scarf or a hat,"

245.text: and I had all these ideas for designs.

248.text: I noticed when I wore my creations,

250.text: people would stop me and say,

251.text: "Wow, that's really cute. Where can I get one?"

253.text: And I thought, I can start my own business.

256.text: Now I didn't have any business plans

260.text: I only knew I wanted to make pretty creations

262.text: that were safe for the environment

263.text: and I wanted to give back.

265.text: My mom taught me how to sew,

267.text: and on my back porch, I would sit and make

271.text:
and I would write down the names
and the price of each item.

273.text: I started making more items like hats,

278.text: Soon, my items began selling all over the world,

280.text: and I had customers in Denmark, Italy, Australia,

285.text: Now, I had a lot to learn about my business,

291.text: and seeing what sold the most and the least.

295.text: Soon, my business really started to take off.

297.text:
Then one day, Forbes magazine 
contacted me when I was 10 years old.

303.text: They wanted to feature me and my company

308.text: Now a lot of people ask me,

312.text: I've had a passion for protecting the environment

315.text: and its creatures since I was little.

317.text: My parents taught me at an early age

319.text:
about giving back and being a
good steward to the environment.

322.text: I heard about how the dyes in some clothing

324.text: or the process of even making the items

326.text: was harmful to the people and the planet,

329.text: so I started doing my own research,

331.text:
and I discovered that even
after dyeing has being completed,

334.text: there is a waste issue that gives a negative impact

338.text: For example, the grinding of materials,

339.text: or the dumping of dried powder materials.

342.text: These actions can pollute the air,

344.text: making it toxic to anyone or anything that inhales it.

348.text: So when I started my business,

352.text: All of my items had to be eco-friendly,

354.text: and 10 to 20 percent of the profits I made

356.text: went to local and global charities

364.text: I feel I'm part of the new wave of entrepreneurs

367.text: that not only seeks to have a successful business,

372.text: I feel that I can meet the needs of my customers

374.text:
without compromising the
ability of future generations

376.text: to live in a greener tomorrow.

379.text: We live in a big, diverse and beautiful world,

382.text: and that makes me even more passionate to save it.

384.text:
But it's never enough to just
to get it through your heads

387.text: about the things that are happening in our world.

389.text: It takes to get it through your hearts,

391.text: because when you get it through your heart,

393.text: that is when movements are sparked.

398.text: and that is why ideas come to life.

401.text: Thank you, and peace and blessings.

414.text: Pat Mitchell: So, you heard Maya talk about

418.text: the amazing parents who are behind

420.text: this incredible woman. Where are they?

423.text: Please, Mr. and Mrs. Penn. Would you just -- Ah!
